condition.description:
Nausea is an uneasy or unsettled feeling in the stomach together with an urge to vomit. Nausea and vomiting, or throwing up, are not diseases. They can be symptoms of many different conditions. These include morning sickness during pregnancy, infections, migraine headaches, motion sickness, food poisoning, cancer chemotherapy or other medicines.

For vomiting in children and adults, avoid solid foods until vomiting has stopped for at least six hours. Then work back to a normal diet. Drink small amounts of clear liquids to avoid dehydration.

Nausea and vomiting are common. Usually, they are not serious. You should see a doctor immediately if you suspect poisoning or if you have

  • Vomited for longer than 24 hours
  • Blood in the vomit
  • Severe abdominal pain
  • Headache and stiff neck
  • Signs of dehydration, such as dry mouth, infrequent urination or dark urine
indications: nausea and vomiting caused by surgery
nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy
nausea and vomiting from radiation therapy

carousel_items: Hydroxyzine shouldn't be taken if you're taking other medications that slow down the nervous system, like narcotics and barbiturates.
Can cause drowsiness or dizziness. Hydroxyzine shouldn't be mixed with other medicines that cause drowsiness like other antihistamines, pain or sleep medications or alcohol.
Side effects are more likely in older adults and young children.
Takes about 2 hours for full antihistamine effect if you’re taking it for itching or rash.

basics.benefits_moa: Hydroxyzine is an antihistamine. It treats allergy symptoms by stopping the effects of histamine in the body.  It's also used to control anxiety before surgery.
basics.bottom_line: Hydroxyzine is an effective treatment for the itching caused by an allergic reaction. It can also help treat mild anxiety.
downsides: The dose of Hydroxyzine should be reduced for people who are older or who have reduced liver or kidney function.
Hydroxyzine can cause confusion, dry mouth, constipation, and urinary side effects. These symptoms are worse in older people.
As with some medicines, the tablets contain lactose. If you’re lactose intolerant, you could be sensitive to this.
Not recommended if you’re pregnant or breastfeeding.
Shouldn't take other medicines that cause drowsiness or dizziness.

Shouldn't take other medicines that cause drowsiness or dizziness.

upsides: Hydroxyzine can be used to treat mild cases of anxiety, and for alcohol withdrawal.
Can be a better option for some people to treat anxiety than more addicting medications like benzodiazepines.
Hydroxyzine is available as a liquid or as tablets.
It can be taken with or without food.

userStories.tip:
First got Urticaria (hives) over 30 years ago. Unknown origin / source. Eventually abated on its own. 
Four years later, had a second outbreak. This time, Dr. prescribed Atarax (Hydroxyzine HCl). It works like magic! Been using it since.
I had a severe case of shingles. The pain was tolerable. The itching was not. Atarax saved me. Stopped the itching and allowed me to finally sleep.
take it in the 8pm area each night - because it will make you drowsy

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Hydroxyzine lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful and avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert and sleepy

description_processed.orig: Hydroxyzine lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful and avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Hydroxyzine can cause birth defects. It's not clear, but the risk may be greater early in pregnancy. Since it's not known if Hydroxyzine passes into breast milk, breast-feeding isn't recommended. Don't use Hydroxyzine while pregnant and if you're considering having a baby and talk to your doctor about alternative medications. If antihistamines are needed to treat severe itching, second generation medicines may be preferred.

risks_warnings.title: Increased side effects
risks_warnings.description: Hydroxyzine is considered a high risk medicine in older people. It can increase the risk of falls, worsen glaucoma, urinary, and prostate problems. If you take Hydroxyzine, use the lowest possible dose and watch for side effects like confusion, dry mouth, constipation, or problems urinating. It’s better to use short-term for severe itching than for long-term treatment of anxiety.

carousel_items: Compro comes in different forms. Be clear on which one you were prescribed - swallow tablets orally, unwrap and insert suppositories rectally.
You'll likely feel very sleepy, sluggish, or less alert after taking Compro. Avoid driving or other tasks that require your focused attention; be safe.
Don't drink alcohol to avoid intense side effects.
Taking certain medications for pain, allergies, or mood conditions can worsen the side effects of Compro.
Avoid using if you experience seizures (epilepsy).
Don't use if you're 65 or older because you're at higher risk for serious side effects.

basics.benefits_moa: Compro is an antiemetic (anti-nausea medicine). It works by blocking signals in the part of your brain that causes vomiting.
basics.bottom_line: Compro can be used to treat severe nausea and vomiting and can be taken orally or rectally, but get ready for a nap.
downsides: Can make you really drowsy. Drinking alcohol with it can make the drowsiness even worse.
Can't be used by people over 65 because they can be more affected by the side effects.
It can make you more likely to get heatstroke.

carousel_items: Promethazine comes in different forms. Be clear on which one you were prescribed - swallow tablets orally, unwrap and insert suppositories rectally.
Don't give to kids 2 and under.
You'll likely feel very sleepy, sluggish, or less alert after taking Promethazine. Avoid driving or other tasks that require your focused attention; be safe.
Don't drink alcohol to avoid intense side effects.
Taking certain medications for pain, allergies, or mood conditions can worsen the side effects of Promethazine.
Avoid using if you experience seizures (epilepsy).
Don't use if you're 65 or older because you're at higher risk for serious side effects.

basics.benefits_moa: Promethazine is an antihistamine, which helps control allergies. It also seems to block your body's natural reflex for vomiting, which makes it useful as an antiemetic (anti-nausea medicine).
basics.bottom_line: Promethazine is used to treat and prevent nausea and vomiting from surgery, motion sickness, or pregnancy. While it's cheap and available in different forms to make it easier to take, it can make you feel very sleepy, and its side effects mean that children under 2 and adults over 65 shouldn't take it.
downsides: Can make you feel very sleepy, especially if you're taking other drugs that can make you sleepy or if you drink alcohol.
Can't be used in children under 2 years of age or if you're over 65 because of increased risk from side effects.
Can make your skin more sensitive to the sun.

carousel_items: If you're using the disintegrating tablet, make sure your hands are dry first, peel off the foil and remove the tablet. Place the tablet on the tongue to let it dissolve naturally, then swallow. Don't drink water or anything else.

If you're taking the oral film, don't chew or swallow it. Let it dissolve naturally on the tongue.
It takes 30 minutes for Zofran to start working.

basics.benefits_moa: Zofran is an antiemetic (anti-nausea medicine). It works by blocking the nerves that cause your nausea and vomiting reflex.
basics.bottom_line: Zofran works well to prevent nausea and vomiting, and it's available in different forms that you don't have to swallow.
downsides: Can cause headaches.
Can interact with antidepressants.
Can only be used to prevent nausea and vomiting, not to treat if it's already happening.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Zofran with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, medications for migraine headaches, and St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hospital right away if you have symptoms.

Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hospital right away if you have symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Heart rhythm problems
risks_warnings.description: If you've ever been told that you've had problems with your heartbeat or heart rhythm, especially long QT syndrome, tell your doctor before you start taking Zofran. This can cause problems with your heart.

risks_warnings.description: People have reported problems in their eyes after taking Scopolamine. This is very rare, but people who already have glaucoma can be more likely to have it. Remove the patch and call your doctor if you suddenly feel pain in your eyes, reddening in your eyes, or changes in how you see.

risks_warnings.title: Heatstroke
risks_warnings.description: People who are taking Scopolamine can be more likely to get heatstroke. Avoid heavy exercising if you have to use Scopolamine, drink plenty of fluids, and avoid being out in the sun or in a very warm environment.

description_processed.orig: People who are taking Scopolamine can be more likely to get heatstroke. Avoid heavy exercising if you have to use Scopolamine, drink plenty of fluids, and avoid being out in the sun or in a very warm environment.

risks_warnings.title: Skin burns
risks_warnings.description: If you're going to have an MRI, make sure to take Scopolamine off before you start, or tell your doctor. It can cause burns on your skin if you leave it on during an MRI.

risks_warnings.title: Seizures
risks_warnings.description: Talk to your doctor if you've had a history of seizures before taking Scopolamine, since it can make you more likely to have them. Your doctor may have to change the dosing of your medications used to control them.

description_processed.orig: Talk to your doctor if you've had a history of seizures before taking Scopolamine, since it can make you more likely to have them. Your doctor may have to change the dosing of your medications used to control them.

risks_warnings.title: Mood problems | Psychosis
risks_warnings.description: Talk to your doctor if you've had a history of mood disorders or psychosis before taking Scopolamine, since the medication can make it worse. Your doctor may have to change the dosing of your medications used to control it.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Scopolamine lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

basics.benefits_moa: Zofran is an antiemetic (anti-nausea medicine). It works by blocking the nerves that cause your nausea and vomiting reflex.
basics.bottom_line: Zofran works well to prevent nausea and vomiting, and it's available in different forms that you don't have to swallow.
downsides: Can cause headaches.
Can interact with antidepressants.
Can only be used to prevent nausea and vomiting, not to treat if it's already happening.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Zofran with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, medications for migraine headaches, and St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hospital right away if you have symptoms.

It can cause dizziness, drowsiness, and can lower your blood pressure.
For the first week, avoid activities like driving that require you to be alert.

basics.benefits_moa: Haloperidol is a traditional antipsychotic. Researchers don't know exactly how it works, but it seems to change dopamine activity in your brain, which affects thoughts and mood.
basics.bottom_line: Haloperidol is okay for treating psychosis and agitation. It's less likely to cause weight gain than other antipsychotics, but it's more likely to cause other bad side effects.
downsides: It's an older medicine and has a lot more side effects than newer antipsychotics.
Compared to other antipsychotics, it causes more hormone problems that can cause nipples to leak fluid, and sudden, dangerous abnormal heart rhythms.

Has a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS): movement disorders that include stiffness, tremor, restlessness, and slow, repetitive, or involuntary movements. One of these symptoms (called tardive dyskinesia) is permanent and more likely if you take this medicine for many years.
You might need routine blood tests to check how the medicine is affecting your body.
All antipsychotics have side effects that make them difficult to take. You might need to try a few different medicines until you find one that works best for you.

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Haloperidol can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away. You may need routine blood tests while on this medication.

risks_warnings.title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
risks_warnings.description: This is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with all antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medications. Symptoms include high fever, fast heart rate, full body stiffness, and confusion. Seek medical attention immediately.

description_processed.orig: This is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with all antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medications. Symptoms include high fever, fast heart rate, full body stiffness, and confusion. Seek medical attention immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Shaking and restlessness

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Dizziness and falls may occur due to a sudden drop in blood pressure when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. If symptoms persist, a different medication may be better for you.

carousel_items: Chew or dissolve chewable tablets in mouth.
Shake Pepto Bismol liquid well before using. Use dosing cup that comes with bottle to get the best dose.
You can take a dose every 1/2 to 1 hour but don't take more than 8 doses in 24 hours.
Chewable tablets and liquid are not for children under 12 years.
Use until diarrhea stops but not more than 2 days. Let your doctor know if your symptoms don't go away after 2 days.
Don't take Pepto Bismol if you have an allergy to aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Don't give Pepto Bismol to children or teenagers who have or are getting better from chickenpox, the flu or other viral sickness because of the risk of getting Reye's Syndrome. Reye's syndrome causes brain and liver damage.
Can temporarily make your tongue and stools darker.
Stop taking Pepto Bismol and tell your doctor if you notice ringing in your ears, unusual bleeding, or nausea and vomiting.
Not a good choice if you have stomach bleeding, bleeding problems, diabetes, gout or are taking medicines to thin your blood.

basics.benefits_moa: Pepto Bismol is a stomach and intestine medicine with multiple effects. It relieves diarrhea by helping your intestines absorb water and electrolytes, and by lowering intestine inflammation and movement. It also has antibacterial and antacid effects.
basics.bottom_line: Pepto Bismol does it all, from upset stomach to crampy diarrhea.
downsides: You might be surprised that Pepto Bismol can cause temporary darkening of your tongue, but it's harmless.
Doesn't treat every intestinal infection so make sure you let your doctor know if your diarrhea and symptoms last more than 2 days or your symptoms get worse. You may need a stronger medicine.

downsides_processed.orig: You might be surprised that Pepto Bismol can cause temporary darkening of your tongue, but it's harmless.
Doesn't treat every intestinal infection so make sure you let your doctor know if your diarrhea and symptoms last more than 2 days or your symptoms get worse. You may need a stronger medicine.

upsides: Most people who take Pepto Bismol feel there's no hassle and it's definitely worth it!
It's can also be used as part of treatment plan for H. Pylori., a stomach infection. H. Pylori is thought to be one of the reasons some people get ulcers.
It comes in caplets, liquid, and chewable tablets so you can use it anywhere you need it.

risks_warnings.title: Risk to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Using Pepto Bismol, an aspirin-type medicine is not recommended during pregnancy. Talk to your baby doctor about other medication choices to treat your condition.

risks_warnings.title: Allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Pepto Bismol breaks down into salicylic acid or aspirin in the body after you swallow it. People who are allergic to aspirin can have a reaction to Pepto Bismol. Stop taking Pepto Bismol and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor or get medical help right away.

description_processed.orig: Pepto Bismol breaks down into salicylic acid or aspirin in the body after you swallow it. People who are allergic to aspirin can have a reaction to Pepto Bismol. risks_warnings.title: Bleeding problems
risks_warnings.description: Pepto Bismol breaks down into salicylic acid or aspirin in the body after you swallow it. If you have a history of stomach or intestinal problems that include ulcers or bleeding or if you have a bleeding problem (hemophilia) you may be at risk of bleeding. The chances this happens is greater the longer you take this medication but it can happen at any time. Call your doctor and get medical care right away if you have blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

risks_warnings.title: Hearing problems

carousel_items: Reglan can cause drowsiness, so avoid driving and other activities that require you to be alert.
Most doctors prescribe Reglan 4 times a day, 30 minutes before each meal, and before bed.
Don’t drink alcohol or take with other drugs that slow your body down until you know how Reglan affects you.
Contact a doctor immediately if you begin to have repetitive movements of the eyes, tongue, face, arm, or legs.
It can take several weeks before Reglan works best for diabetic gastroparesis; so don’t give up on it.

basics.benefits_moa: Reglan is an antiemetic and prokinetic medication that helps contract and stimulate your stomach. This helps to pass food along, while lowering acid reflux, nausea, and vomiting.
basics.bottom_line: Reglan helps get your digestive system moving and lowers nausea and vomiting. Using it a long time can come with serious, potentially permanent side effects.
downsides: You can’t use Reglan for more than 12 weeks since it can lead to involuntary movements of the eyes, tongue, face, arm, or legs.
Reglan is no longer recommended for acid reflux because of its long list of side effects and the availability of better medications.
It can take several weeks for Reglan to begin working for diabetic gastroparesis.
If you take Reglan for more than 12 weeks, there can be serious side effects and you'll have to get your blood checked often.

downsides_processed.orig: You can’t use Reglan for more than 12 weeks since it can lead to involuntary movements of the eyes, tongue, face, arm, or legs.
Reglan is no longer recommended for acid reflux because of its long list of side effects and the availability of better medications.
It can take several weeks for Reglan to begin working for diabetic gastroparesis.
If you take Reglan for more than 12 weeks, there can be serious side effects and you'll have to get your blood checked often.

upsides: Reglan stops the chance of vomiting for about one-third of the people who take it.
Gets stomach fluids moving after surgery or during diabetic gastroparesis. Works well for acid reflux when other medications don’t.
Comes in a generic version, and in multiple forms.

risks_warnings.title: Abnormal and involuntary muscle movements
risks_warnings.description: Reglan can cause muscle stiffness, feelings of restlessness (like you need to move around), and abnormal or uncontrollable facial or body movements, which could be a sign of tardive dyskinesia (TD). Let your doctor know if you experience any of these symptoms. Reglan should not be taken for more than 12 weeks, because these symptoms can become permanent. There is currently no known effective treatment for TD, although, in some patients TD may go away.

Let your doctor know if you experience any of these symptoms. Reglan should not be taken for more than 12 weeks, because these symptoms can become permanent. There is currently no known effective treatment for TD, although, in some patients TD may go away.

risks_warnings.title: Depression
risks_warnings.description: People taking Reglan can experience symptoms of mental depression. This can occur in people with or without a history of depression.

description_processed.orig: People taking Reglan can experience symptoms of mental depression. This can occur in people with or without a history of depression.

risks_warnings.title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
risks_warnings.description: This is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with Reglan. Symptoms include high fever, fast heart rate, stiff muscles, excess sweating, increased heart rate or blood pressure, and confusion. Get medical attention immediately.

description_processed.orig: This is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with Reglan. Symptoms include high fever, fast heart rate, stiff muscles, excess sweating, increased heart rate or blood pressure, and confusion. Get medical attention immediately.

carousel_items: You can crush the tablets and take Hydrocortisone with your food or drink. Do not open up a capsule, since they need to be swallowed whole.
Be sure not to stop taking Hydrocortisone suddenly, as it can lead to loss of appetite, nausea, weakness, low blood pressure, and low blood sugar.
Some people gain weight while taking Hydrocortisone. Using a weight loss program, eating smaller portions, and drinking a glass of water before meals tend to help.

basics.benefits_moa: Hydrocortisone is a short-acting corticosteroid. It lowers inflammation by preventing your capillaries (small blood vessels) from leaking out excess fluid and chemicals that cause swelling.
basics.bottom_line: Hydrocortisone is identical to an essential hormone that humans produce and has been proven to work safely.
downsides: In the first few weeks, your doctor might adjust the dose of Hydrocortisone multiple times.
You may be at an increased risk of infection if you take high doses of Hydrocortisone, or if you take it in combination with other immunosuppressive medications.
Your body could stop making its own cortisol once it gets used to Hydrocortisone. If so, you'll likely have to keep taking Hydrocortisone for a really long time.
Depending on why your doctor prescribed Hydrocortisone to you, corticosteroids can have different effects on your body.

upsides: Normal doses of hydrocortisone have been safely and successfully used for over 60 years. It's especially good for people using it as a long-term cortisol supplement.
Hydrocortisone converts into cortisol, a natural hormone, which will not interfere with other medications you may be taking.
Taking a dose of Hydrocortisone in the evening doesn't affect your ability to sleep.
At safe doses, Hydrocortisone can actually increase your body's ability to fight infection.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression (HPA axis suppression)
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Hydrocortisone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Hydrocortisone dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.
risk_factors: Lowering dose or stopping too quickly especially after long-term treatment
Stress such as trauma, surgery or infection

Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk for infections
risks_warnings.description: If you take Hydrocortisone for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Hydrocortisone. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Hydrocortisone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.
risk_factors: Contact with people who have viral illness
History of bacterial or viral conditions

Talk to your doctor before taking Hydrocortisone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma
risks_warnings.description: It’s rare, but taking Hydrocortisone for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposi’s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Hydrocortisone and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Psychiatric changes
risks_warnings.description: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Hydrocortisone may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Bone effects
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocortisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Taking Hydrocortisone if you're pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma).

risks_warnings.title: Stomach and intestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Hydrocortisone increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: Active or history of stomach or duodenal ulcers

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Zofran with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, medications for migraine headaches, and St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hospital right away if you have symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance and dependence
risks_warnings.description: If you use Ativan for 4 weeks or more, it's likely that your body will develop tolerance to it, which means that more and more of the medication is needed to achieve the same effect. You're also likely to become physically dependent on the medication, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it all at once. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose to minimize risks of abuse and overdose. Ativan should not be used by people with a history of drug abuse if an alternative medication is available.

risks_warnings.title: Withdrawal
risks_warnings.description: Stopping Ativan suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms such as nausea, anxiety, agitation, flu-like symptoms, trouble sleeping, and muscle pain or burning. Withdrawal symptoms can last 6 weeks or longer. Work with your doctor to gradually reduce your dose.

risks_warnings.title: Pregnancy
risks_warnings.description: Ativan can harm a developing fetus. The baby can become dependent on the medicine and go through withdrawal after birth. Don't use Ativan while pregnant.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Ativan impairs your ability to focus, think, and react. These effects can extend to the morning after taking Ativan. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

basics.benefits_moa: Prednisone is a corticosteroid that's similar to what your body naturally makes. It reduces swelling and other immune responses that can cause you pain, discomfort, or harm.
basics.bottom_line: Prednisone is a common oral corticosteroid that's great for controlling the unwanted symptoms from your immune responses and will make you feel better. There are lots of side effects but most of are tolerable or can be managed.
downsides: Lots of side effects, especially with long term use.
Short-term use can cause mood changes, trouble sleeping and increase in blood pressure, blood sugar, and possible water retention.
Long-term use can cause problems with skin, bone, eye health and put you at a higher risk for infections.
People with certain conditions will have to pay extra attention to their symptoms or may have to adjust the dose of other medicines when taking Prednisone.
When using corticosteroids for more than 1 week, you will need to work with a doctor to get off the medicine slowly.
Only available as an oral medicine so the rest of your body will be exposed to the medicine.

Short-term use in controlling immune responses that are causing you discomfort, and works quickly to relieve symptoms like swelling, rash, asthma attacks, gout attacks.
Long-term use in suppressing the immune system from causing your body harm, like many autoimmune related conditions.

carousel_items_processed.orig: The dose and duration on how long you need the medicine depends on your condition and response.
Take it exactly as your doctor prescribed.
Take with food to decrease stomach upset.
Can cause trouble sleeping. Take in the morning or 2-3 hours before bed if more than one dose is needed.
Can cause changes in mood, blood pressure, blood sugar, and water retention.
You should check your blood pressure and blood sugar when taking this medicine if you already have high blood pressure or diabetes.
A taper is is often needed to stop the medicine, especially if you've been on it for more than 1 week.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression (HPA axis suppression)
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Prednisone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Prednisone dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.
risk_factors: Lowering dose or stopping too quickly especially after long-term treatment
Stress such as trauma, surgery or infection

description_processed.orig: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Prednisone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Prednisone dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk for infections
risks_warnings.description: If you take Prednisone for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Prednisone. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Prednisone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.
risk_factors: Contact with people who have viral illness
History of bacterial or viral conditions

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma
risks_warnings.description: It’s rare, but taking Prednisone for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposi’s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Prednisone and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Eye problems
risks_warnings.description: Prednisone may cause cataracts or glaucoma, increased eye pressure and possibly eye nerve damage. You may also be more at risk for certain eye infections. Don't take if you have herpes simplex of the eye.  Let your doctor know if you have blurry vision, eye pain or any vision changes.

risks_warnings.title: Psychiatric changes
risks_warnings.description: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Prednisone may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Bone effects
risks_warnings.description: Prednisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Prednisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your child’s height during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Taking Prednisone if your pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma). If you're taking Prednisone to treat an autoimmune condition like rheumatoid arthritis or for antirejection treatment after a transplant, there are disease registries that you'll need to contact so make sure you talk to your doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach and intestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Prednisone increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: Active or history of stomach or duodenal ulcers
Taking Prednisone with other medicine that can cause stomach problems

carousel_items: Take Unisom at bedtime as needed if you're 12 years of age or older.
Unisom can make you dehydrated, so avoid this side effect by drinking plenty of fluids.
Don't take it with alcohol or other drugs that make you sleepy.
If you need to use it for more than a few weeks, talk with your doctor. A different medication might work better for you long-term.
Unisom comes in two different generic forms, doxylamine (Unisom SleepTabs) and diphenhydramine (other Unisom products). Both are antihistamines that help you sleep.

basics.benefits_moa: Unisom is an antihistamine. It blocks histamine, a chemical that causes congestion, itching, and other allergic reactions. It also makes you sleepy.
basics.bottom_line: Unisom is a good over-the-counter medication for nighttime allergies.
downsides: Unisom makes you more tired than Claritin, Allegra, or Zyrtec.
You shouldn't drive after taking Unisom until you know how it affects you.
Talk to a pediatrician before giving Unisom to a child.
It can increase the risk of falls, so elderly people shouldn't use Unisom.
Don't use Unisom if you are breastfeeding.

It can provide quick relief of allergy symptoms for both kids and adults.
It makes you sleepy, so it'll help if your allergies are bothering you at night.

It comes as a tablet, capsule, liquid, and quick dissolving tablet.

risks_warnings.title: Overdose
risks_warnings.description: There are a variety of over-the-counter medications with the same ingredients as Unisom. It's not safe to use more than one medication containing diphenhydramine (the ingredient in Unisom) at the same time. Read package labels carefully to make sure you take the right dose of these medications.
risk_factors: Using other drugs with the same ingredients

risks_warnings.title: Increased side effects
risks_warnings.description: People age 65 years and older have a higher risk of side effects from taking antihistamine medications like Unisom. Watch for changes in vision, severe dry mouth, trouble urinating, or constipation. The drowsiness caused by Unisom can make you "unsteady" on your feet, leading to a higher chance of falls.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Unisom can lower your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Hyperactivity

basics.benefits_moa: Zyprexa is an atypical antipsychotic. Researchers don't know exactly how it works. It seems to change dopamine and serotonin activity in your brain, which affects thoughts and mood.
basics.bottom_line: Zyprexa is good for treating psychosis, mania, and agitation. More likely to cause weight gain and sleepiness than other antipsychotics.
downsides: More likely to cause weight gain and problems with cholesterol or blood sugar compared to other antipsychotics.
Might make you more sleepy than some antipsychotics.
Mild risk of Extrapyramidal Symptoms (EPS): Movement disorders that include stiffness, tremor, restlessness, and slow, repetitive, or involuntary movements.
You might need routine blood tests to check how the medicine is affecting your body.
All antipsychotics come with side effects that make them difficult to take. You might need to try a few different medicines until you find one that works for you and that you can tolerate.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk of death
risks_warnings.description: Older patients with dementia-related psychosis have a higher risk of death when treated with antipsychotic medications. Zyprexa is not approved to treat dementia-related psychosis.

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Zyprexa can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away. You may need routine blood tests while on this medication.

risks_warnings.title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
risks_warnings.description: This is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with all antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medications. Symptoms include high fever, fast heart rate, full body stiffness, and confusion. Seek medical attention immediately.

description_processed.orig: This is a rare but life-threatening condition associated with all antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medications. Symptoms include high fever, fast heart rate, full body stiffness, and confusion. Seek medical attention immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Dizziness and falls may occur due to a sudden drop in blood pressure when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. If symptoms persist, a different medication may be better for you.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Zofran with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, medications for migraine headaches, and St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hospital right away if you have symptoms.
